newsitem.title: GERMANY: SOCCER-VOGTS CALLS FOR CHANGE IN QUALIFYING STRUCTURE.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-VOGTS CALLS FOR CHANGE IN QUALIFYING STRUCTURE.

text.p: German coach Berti Vogts hit out at the current qualifying structure for international tournaments on Friday and called for a shake-up in time for the 2000 European Championships.

Vogts wanted to see a reduction in the number of qualifying matches to reduce fixture congestion and the sort of potentially one-sided games which Germany face in their World Cup group against Albania, Ukraine and Armenia.
"We're on a hiding to nothing," he said. "Until we play our game in Berlin against (group second favourites) Portugal, the fans and the media will be expecting victories as a matter of course.
"We won't get even favourable headlines unless we win at least 5-0, and even then three of them will have to be 'Goals of the Month'."

Vogts suggested that the system being used for the 1998 World Cup where nine groups will, through a series of play-offs, eventually produce 14 European qualifiers should be simplified for the European Championships.
He advocated a system of 14 smaller groups with the winners progressing to the finals where they would join co-hosts Belgium and the Netherlands.
Vogts said cutting group sizes would not only reduce the physical pressures on players but also leave time for more lucrative friendlies againts top nations.
"Maybe we could think about a tournament with Italy, France, Spain, the Netherlands, England and us," he said.
